job_title: Rn Admissions/ transfer center  in Visalia, CA
pros: RN Admissions or bed allocation job is super easy. Can be stressful when the hospital is at capacity and no beds for admissions. Transfer Center inpatient transfers out of the hospital. The main thing you do is call the other hospitals ask if they have the service and then transfer the patient there based on if the receiving hospital accepts and the patients insurance approves it.
cons: The department is tiny and you really have to be cool with everyone or else it's awkward. There is currently a department reconstruction so functions and duties will change.

pros: Good place to learn for medical field students.

cons: During Covid, this company spent $800,000 on rebranding, while denying annual raises and halting their 401k match. Overall pay is low. $41/hr for a nurse in California is low.

pros: Good team/staff, lots of opportunity to work overtime
cons: Constantly short staffed, so no schedule flexibility. When they try and cut costs it’s taken directly from employees. Pandemic= no more retirement matching, increased health insurance premiums, no annual bonus etc. we hardly earn vacation and sick leave, at 4 months I had earned a day. It’s clear that employees education development isn’t valued at all- I’ll have to quit to further my education. Over 12 hours in a shift isn’t overtime pay- only over 40 hours in a week, mandatory docking without pay is frequent, when the hospital is short you can be floated anywhere regardless of your specialty. Holiday pay isn’t time and a half, it’s like 10% more or something.

review_title: Great teamwork, Great schedule - but lots of new nurses, lots of turnover
job_title: Staff RN I in Visalia, CA
pros:
Great schedule flexibilty - full-time RNs here work three 12-hour shifts per week, and have a lot of say in how their schedule is made.

Great teamwork - feel very supportive and supported by my coworkers here. My manager is great too, and really listens to us.
cons:
Pay for RNs is mediocre. Lots of patients only speak Spanish, which can be difficult.

Also, lots of turnover with nurses coming from the Bay Area to get experience, and then leaving. Frequent staffing shortages, but hey what hospital doesn't, right?

review_title: No support in the outpatient clinics and totally disconnected from the hospital-treated like step kids
pros: Competitive pay, great support if you attend college, tuition reimbursement.
cons: The pay is competitive, this is a nurse magnet hospital, they focus on "happy employees make happy patients" BUT they need to realize that treating employees great is one thing but NOT holding staff accountable or allowing lazy people to get away with doing nothing while your great employees do all the work. In fact, I just got another job because after X amount of years I decided that the work culture will not change so I quit. If my boss would allow all management to be treated equal that would be great. But, according to "seniority" some staff are not given the same treatment. We are bypassed and made to feel like second-class citizens.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Visalia, CA
pros: Honestly there are  none, that come to mind.   Especially when comparing against other employers I've worked for.
cons:
Management in the Finance Department is extremely unprofessional, power hungry, and creates a very hostile work environment.  There are so many odd and unnecessary politics, that go on in this department.  

It has truly been an uncomfortable and upsetting experience to have worked here for me.  I am very thankful that I have moved on to another job, and am no longer working here.

FYI - The building that the Finance Department resides in is very old and filthy.  It is full of odd allergies.  There is definitely something very unhealthy residing in this building.

pros: Co-workers were great, some doctors are good to work with.
cons: Upper management is poor. Achieved magnet status by hand picking the rn's to interview and fed us all the lines to say to interviewees. Poor pay , No OT after 8 hrs. If you speak your mind, you might lose your job. They always find a way to take more from you and give you less. Very political upper management. Never once in 7 years did any of them introduce themselves or say hi when walking through the halls. You are just a number here.

pros: Workflow runs much more smoothly than most hospitals. For nurses and CNAs the charting is simple and easier than Curner. Salary is better for nurses.
cons: The culture sucks. A lot of bullying among staff. I've seen 4 nurses in my unit alone leave because of workplace harassment. I heard of a few more when I moved to another facility l. Telemetry had a huge turnover rate. When I transitioned from full time to per firm in Tele to go to nursing school, the manager asked me to consider a pay deduction. I worked there for 5 years, if you're going to work less hours, shouldn't you get more? This is the culture of Kaweah. You are nothing more than a body filling in a shift.

review_title: Think about leaving your current job, before coming to Kaweah
pros: I Have a job. Some of the co workers are awesome
cons: Lack of training. Managers and Coordinators dont have a college education or health care experience. Managers and Coordinators are allowed to talk to an employee any way they want without getting into trouble. Higher up has no clue what goes on in each department, Managers and Directors tell whatever they want to hear and they believe them. Money is wasted leaving the employees with no raises. If you dont have a BA degree you dont get a 3.00 an hr raise, the monkeys spinning the wheel arent appreciated they're lucky if they get a couple of cents. Higher ups need to come and do our job for our pay..

pros: Pay was better than most nursing jobs.  If you don't know what you're doing, you'll still have a job.  Compartmentalization will solve cognitive dissonance (You'll do a lot before you realize what you have done).
cons: It would be illegal for me to say what really goes on in that place.  You might want to speak with the IT team if you want to know what happens with electronic medical records.  If you can't prove something happens because it was recorded electronically and you try to say it out loud or write it down, it can be slander or libel.

review_title: KDHCD: A small town hospital that isn't anymore but the culture hasn't changed with the times.
pros:
1. People
2. Benefits
3. Opportunity
4. Pay is competitive.
cons:
1. Executive Leadership disconnected with how hospital truly operates.
2. Physician/Staff culture: very much an "us" vs. 'them' culture.

review_title: It was ok, hard to get a full time position.
pros: Working part time has pluses such as flexible hours and days. Able to go to school while working.
cons: The schedule is flexible and so is the pay. I could not count on a specific salary because even if I COULD work 40 hours, they were not available for me one week, but possibly the next.

review_title: Great stepping stone to start a career in health care!
pros: They work well with your time off request. Decent benefits, very friendly work environment get to know many individuals around the District. You are not micromanaged.
cons: No holidays (the use of personal PTO for any event). Management sometimes has no backbone to Stand by employees. Need more department cohesion. Continuing education opportunities are limited. Freezes on salary increases while hospital is still making good profit margins.

job_title: Physical Therapist Assistant in Visalia, CA
pros: large capacity serving numerous healthcare needs. variety of patients leading to increased experience, knowledge base, opportunity for growth. excellent healthcare benefits and time off accrual.
cons: under-staffed at times. politics driving decision making. often hasty discharges to open up beds asap when at capacity. minimum float pool for impact help when needed in therapy department.

review_title: I loved working for the district, it's a big hospital being new I never felt comfortable, staff wasn't always friendly.

pros: Great place to work lots of opportunities to grow and advance.

pros: Good wages and benefits, supportive manager, flexible with my schedule and needs, opportunity to work in different specialties, great patients

pros: Kaweah Delta stays on top of the latest technology and constantly strives to help employee better themselves and how they deliver care to their customers.  Kaweah Delta has excellent salary and benefits.
cons: Kaweah Delta is such a large employer that it is easy to get lost in the middle of 4300 employees; however, this is a problem all big companies face.

job_title: Executive Director Tech in Visalia, CA
pros: Most nurses and techs work together as a team. There are a lot of residents and doctors around every corner, and all have been approachable for questions or concerns. It is a level 3 trauma so you'll learn a lot of good knowledge. The ED manager is very easy to get a hold of.
cons: Pay for techs is low.  Most people start out in nights. Not a lot of parking.

pros: flexible and lower staff friendly. Great place to work if you're laid back and like slow pace. If you're a shaker and mover; not for you.
cons: Does not pay attention to staffs needs at clinics. Using old equipment and furniture. Leadership and managers spin wheels and lazy staff rarely held accountable.

pros: Compensation is decent. Schedule flexibility is not bad either/
cons: disorganized. Management is not as great as they think they are.  Lack of staffing causes a lot of work for floor nurses. Food in the cafeteria is terrible.

pros: Positive work environment, the organization is well respected in the community, invests in employee and their development, open to feedback and positive changes, great coworkers, strong values, amazing benefits and competitive salary

pros: Desperate for RNs at this time. easy to get hired for new grads, no political drama. Bonus pay for overtime is significant

pros: The other stressed out nurses.

Constantly out off ratio even though California has set ratios they break them every shift. Leads take full groups so they are not a resource for all the new nurses, since so many veteran nurses have left to find more supportive hospitals to work in. Sentinel effect waiting to happen.
